conclusion: Concepts from physics are used to determine the magnitude of the electric field strength.
The force acting on the charged particle in the electric field is given by F = qE.
The acceleration a of the particle is given by a = qE/m using Newton's second law.
The particle starts with zero initial velocity at point A and its final speed at point C is v0.
The work done by the electric field on the particle is equal to the change in kinetic energy.
The work done by the electric field is W = qEx.
The change in kinetic energy is ΔK = 1/2 mv0^2.
The distance x is the component of the displacement AC along the direction of the electric field.
Given θ = 60°, the distance x can be expressed as x = R/2.
Setting the work done by the electric field equal to the change in kinetic energy: qE(R/2) = 1/2 mv0^2.
Solving for E gives E = mv0^2/(qR).
The magnitude of the electric field strength E is mv0^2/(qR).
